Package com.phasmidsoftware.dsaipg.graphs.gis

Class ShortestPaths<V,E extends Number>

java.lang.Object
com.phasmidsoftware.dsaipg.graphs.gis.ShortestPaths<V,E>
Type Parameters:
V - the type of vertices in the graph.
E - the type of edge weights, extending Number.
public class ShortestPaths<V,E extends Number> extends Object
The ShortestPaths class is designed to compute the shortest paths from a starting vertex to all other vertices in a directed graph using Dijkstra's algorithm. This class is generic and works with any vertex and edge types, provided that edges have numeric weights.

    Constructs a ShortestPaths object to calculate the shortest paths from a given starting vertex within a directed graph using Dijkstra's algorithm.

  • Constructor Details

    • ShortestPaths

      public ShortestPaths(DiGraph<V,E> graph, V start)
      Constructs a ShortestPaths object to calculate the shortest paths from a given starting vertex within a directed graph using Dijkstra's algorithm.
      Parameters:
      graph - the directed graph on which shortest path calculations will be performed
      start - the starting vertex from which shortest paths will be computed

  • Method Details

    • cost

      public double cost(V v)

    • hasPathTo

      public boolean hasPathTo(V v)
      Determines whether there is a path from the starting vertex to the specified vertex.
      Parameters:
      v - the vertex to check for a path from the starting vertex
      Returns:
      true if a path exists to the specified vertex, false otherwise

    • pathTo

      public Iterable<Edge<V,E>> pathTo(V target)
      Computes and returns an iterable sequence of edges representing the path from the starting vertex to the specified target vertex in the graph. The path is determined based on the shortest paths previously calculated and stored in the data structure.
      Parameters:
      target - the target vertex for which the path from the start vertex is to be retrieved
      Returns:
      an iterable of edges representing the path from the start vertex to the target vertex; returns an empty iterable if no path exists
